Four decades in, and Excel‚Äôs gone from spreadsheet to sentient strategist. Agent Mode doesn‚Äôt just calculate‚Äîit reflects, revises, and reasons like a caffeinated philosopher with a clipboard. But here‚Äôs the rub: when AI starts executing tasks, validating itself, and grading its own output, who‚Äôs holding the ethical clipboard? Agent Mode promises auditability and transparency‚Äîbut only within the grid. Outside it? We‚Äôre outsourcing judgment to a loop that never sleeps, never questions its purpose, and never asks: ‚ÄúShould I?‚Äù It‚Äôs brilliant, yes. But brilliance without boundaries is how we end up with cognitive weapons disguised as productivity tools. If AI can now simulate expert fluency, what stops it from simulating authority, consensus, or even truth? And let‚Äôs talk power. This isn‚Äôt just about helping users‚Äîit‚Äôs about shaping how knowledge is structured, interpreted, and acted upon. Quietly, Excel becomes not just a tool, but a decision-making proxy. That‚Äôs not just innovation. That‚Äôs epistemological colonisation. So yes, hats off to the engineers. But someone needs to ask: when the loop reflects, does it ever reflect on us?
